issues.title: Frontend: Implement Responsive Design for Mobile (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Ensure the frontend displays properly across all screen sizes, especially mobile devices. Many AOSSIE projects have frontends where element sizes do not adjust well for smaller screens.

## Tasks
- [ ] Audit all pages for mobile responsiveness
- [ ] Implement responsive CSS using media queries or modern frameworks
- [ ] Test on various screen sizes (mobile, tablet, desktop)
- [ ] Ensure touch-friendly interactive elements (minimum 44x44px)
- [ ] Fix any text overflow or layout breaking issues
- [ ] Optimize images for different screen sizes
- [ ] Test on actual mobile devices (iOS and Android)
- [ ] Ensure proper viewport meta tag is set
- [ ] Verify navigation/menu works well on mobile
- [ ] Check that all buttons and forms are easily usable on mobile

## Best Practices
- Use mobile-first approach
- Use relative units (rem, em, %, vw, vh) instead of fixed pixels
- Test across multiple devices and browsers
- Consider using CSS frameworks with built-in responsiveness
- Ensure proper spacing and padding for touch targets

## Resources
- [Responsive Web Design Basics](https://web.dev/responsive-web-design-basics/)
- [MDN Responsive Design Guide](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/CSS/CSS_layout/Responsive_Design)

issues.body:
## Description
Implement rate limiting on API endpoints to prevent abuse, DDoS attacks, and ensure fair usage across all users.

## Tasks
- [ ] Identify endpoints that need rate limiting
- [ ] Choose rate limiting strategy (IP-based, user-based, or both)
- [ ] Implement rate limiting middleware
- [ ] Define rate limits for different endpoint types
- [ ] Add proper HTTP 429 responses when limit exceeded
- [ ] Include rate limit headers (X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset)
- [ ] Implement different tiers for authenticated vs anonymous users
- [ ] Add rate limit monitoring and alerts
- [ ] Document rate limits in API documentation
- [ ] Test rate limiting behavior
- [ ] Consider implementing exponential backoff suggestions

## Recommended Limits
- Public endpoints: 100 requests per 15 minutes
- Authenticated users: 1000 requests per hour
- Admin/privileged users: Higher or no limits

## Resources
- [Rate Limiting Strategies](https://cloud.google.com/architecture/rate-limiting-strategies-techniques)

**Note**: If this project doesn't have an API backend, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Gas Optimization Audit (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Audit and optimize smart contract gas usage to reduce transaction costs for users. This is an ongoing task where community members can continuously suggest optimizations.

## Tasks
- [ ] Run gas reporter on all contract functions
- [ ] Identify gas-heavy operations
- [ ] Optimize storage usage (use packed structs, minimize storage writes)
- [ ] Use memory instead of storage where appropriate
- [ ] Optimize loops and iterations
- [ ] Use appropriate data types (uint256 vs smaller types)
- [ ] Remove unnecessary operations and redundant checks
- [ ] Consider using libraries for common operations
- [ ] Batch operations where possible
- [ ] Optimize modifier usage
- [ ] Use events instead of storage for historical data
- [ ] Document gas costs for major operations
- [ ] Compare gas usage before/after optimizations

## Ongoing Optimization
This issue can remain open for community members to continuously suggest and implement gas optimizations as new patterns emerge.

## Resources
- [Gas Optimization Techniques](https://www.rareskills.io/post/gas-optimization)
- [OpenZeppelin Gas Optimization Tips](https://docs.openzeppelin.com/contracts/4.x/api/utils)

**Note**: If this project doesn't involve smart contracts, you can close this issue.

issues.title: Blockchain: Manual Security Audit Checklist (if applicable)
issues.body:
## Description
Perform manual security review of smart contracts against common vulnerabilities.

## Security Checks
- [ ] Reentrancy protection (use ReentrancyGuard)
- [ ] Integer overflow/underflow (use SafeMath or Solidity 0.8+)
- [ ] Access control mechanisms properly implemented
- [ ] Input validation on all external functions
- [ ] Check for unchecked return values
- [ ] Verify proper use of tx.origin vs msg.sender
- [ ] Review delegatecall usage for security
- [ ] Check for front-running vulnerabilities
- [ ] Verify timestamp dependence issues
- [ ] Review randomness generation (avoid block.timestamp)
- [ ] Check for denial of service vulnerabilities
- [ ] Verify proper event logging
- [ ] Review upgrade mechanisms (if proxy pattern used)
- [ ] Check for signature replay attacks
- [ ] Verify proper handling of ETH/token transfers

## Audit Steps
- [ ] Manual code review by team members
- [ ] Create security documentation
- [ ] Consider professional third-party audit
- [ ] Setup bug bounty program

## Resources
- [Smart Contract Security Best Practices](https://consensys.github.io/smart-contract-best-practices/)
- [SWC Registry - Vulnerability Classification](https://swcregistry.io/)
- [OpenZeppelin Security Tools](https://www.openzeppelin.com/security-audits)

**Note**: If this project doesn't involve smart contracts, you can close this issue.

- [ ] Identify all user input points

- [ ] Add sanitization to prevent XSS
- [ ] Validate file uploads (type, size, content)
